title: The woman behind WeWoreWhat has launched a workflow tool for influencers
text:
Danielle Bernstein, the name behind popular fashion influencer WeWoreWhat, has launched a project management platform catered toward influencers.

Called MOE, the platform automates influencers' workflow, organizes multiple projects and campaigns, and sends invoices for brand deals to collect payment.

Bernstein, who has 2.2 million Instagram followers, told Business Insider that MOE is designed for microinfluencers in charge of their own business, and puts "the power back in influencers' hands."

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

There's a slew of project management and workflow apps like Monday and Asana for the workplace, but none of them are tailored-made for influencers whose career work a little differently.

Danielle Bernstein, better known as fashion influencer and blogger WeWoreWhat, has clocked up decade of having "influencer" as her job title. Bernstein announced Tuesday the launch of Moe, an online tool for influencers to manage multiple campaigns, collaborate on projects, and generate invoices to get paid.

"None of the [platforms] out there address the needs of influencers themselves," Bernstein told Business Insider. "We want to put the power back in the influencer's hands ... and it's created by someone who knows the workflow best."

Moe borrows its name from Bernstein's long-time assistant Moe Peretti, who has long been in charge of completing all of these various tasks for the WeWoreWhat brand, and now serves as the its chief brand officer. As Bernstein put it simply to Business Insider: "Everybody needs a Moe."

A screenshot of MOE Assist, WeWoreWhat's influencer workflow manager. Moe Assist Bernstein says Moe is meant for micro-influencers — generally, anyone with between 1,000 and 100,000 followers — who have a growing brand to manage, but aren't yet big enough to hire a team for invoicing and scheduling.

The idea of Moe is to take the place of an assistant who would organize various documents and content across an influencers' email addresses, social media platforms, Google Docs, and whatever else is used. Moe also allows for collaboration on campaigns between influencers and brands, who may need an easy way to share changes and comments on projects.

While much of the work into Moe has been self-funded by Bernstein, Moe has also raised $1.2 million in seed funding from private investors, including fashion brand founder Rebecca Minkoff.

The WeWoreWhat team has beta-tested Moe with around 25 influencers in the last few months ahead of Tuesday's launch, Berstein said.

Moe costs $28 a month to use, and also offers a 30-day free trial to test out before you buy.
description: Danielle Bernstein, the name behind popular fashion influencer WeWoreWhat, released project management platform Moe on Tuesday.
